displayText.simplePara: All AMPEL360 BWB H₂ Hy-E Q100 aircraft

levelledPara.title: General Description
levelledPara.para: This data module provides a general description of the AMPEL360 BWB H₂ Hy-E Q100 aircraft general data, including physical characteristics, configuration, and key design features relevant to maintenance operations.

levelledPara.title: Basic Design
levelledPara.para: The AMPEL360 BWB H₂ Hy-E Q100 is a revolutionary blended wing body (BWB) aircraft featuring hydrogen fuel cell propulsion and distributed electric motors. The aircraft integrates the wing and fuselage into a single lifting surface, providing exceptional aerodynamic efficiency.

levelledPara.title: Propulsion System
levelledPara.para: The aircraft is powered by six PEM (Proton Exchange Membrane) fuel cell stacks, each producing 3 MW of electrical power. Total installed power is 18 MW with a continuous rating of 15 MW. The fuel cells convert liquid hydrogen (LH₂) into electricity with 58% efficiency (HHV basis).

levelledPara.title: Hydrogen Fuel System
levelledPara.para: Six cryogenic hydrogen tanks are integrated into the BWB center section, with a total capacity of 4,500 kg LH₂ stored at -253°C (20 K). The fuel system includes automatic pressure control, temperature management, and safety venting systems.

levelledPara.title: Electric Propulsion
levelledPara.para: Twelve distributed electric motors provide thrust through boundary layer ingestion (BLI) propulsors. Each motor produces 1.25 MW of power, with total thrust capability of 280 kN at sea level. The distributed propulsion system improves efficiency and reduces noise.

levelledPara.title: Center of Gravity Limits
levelledPara.para: The aircraft center of gravity (CG) must be maintained between 15% and 42% of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC). The MAC is 12.5 m in length and is located at fuselage station 15.8 m. An automated fuel transfer system manages CG position during flight.

levelledPara.title: CAOS Digital Twin Integration
levelledPara.para: The aircraft is equipped with the CAOS (Comprehensive Aerospace Operations System) digital twin, which provides real-time monitoring of aircraft parameters, predictive maintenance capabilities, and performance optimization. All maintenance operations interface with the CAOS system for data recording and analysis.

levelledPara.title: Certification Basis
levelledPara.para: The aircraft is certified under EASA CS-25 Amendment 27, FAA FAR Part 25, and hydrogen-specific regulations per EASA SC-H2-01. Special conditions apply for the BWB configuration and AI-integrated CAOS system.
